Articles.Content: The speeds of sound and light in KSP are instantaneous. I'm not sure how you got that data...

Huh? I was always taught and read that the speed of sound is highest at sea level then decreases the higher you go "because gas molecules move more slowly at colder temperatures, which slows the speed of sound; sound moves faster through warmer air. Therefore, the speed required to break the sound barrier decreases higher in the atmosphere, where temperatures are colder."

This is one example of what I'm referring to:

Granted this chart starts with a sea level temperature of 15 celsius which can influence exactly what the speed of sound is.

[http://www.fighter-planes.com/jetmach1.htm](http://www.fighter-planes.com/jetmach1.htm)

> 
> The speeds of sound and light in KSP are instantaneous. I'm not sure how you got that data...

He is referring to the effects of the speed of sound in aerodynamics, not the literal sound. Mach numbers are commonly used for a reason, and KSP simulates some effects of drag and heating as one breaks the sound barrier.

- - - Updated - - -

> 
> Huh? I was always taught and read that the speed of sound is highest at sea level then decreases the higher you go "because gas molecules move more slowly at colder temperatures, which slows the speed of sound; sound moves faster through warmer air. Therefore, the speed required to break the sound barrier decreases higher in the atmosphere, where temperatures are colder."
> This is one example of what I'm referring to:
> 
> Granted this chart starts with a sea level temperature of 15 celsius which can influence exactly what the speed of sound is.
> 
> [http://www.fighter-planes.com/jetmach1.htm](http://www.fighter-planes.com/jetmach1.htm)

Pressure also has something to do with it, and [some parts of the atmosphere are much hotter than you might expect.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thermosphere)

> 
> Huh? I was always taught and read that the speed of sound is highest at sea level then decreases the higher you go "because gas molecules move more slowly at colder temperatures, which slows the speed of sound; sound moves faster through warmer air. Therefore, the speed required to break the sound barrier decreases higher in the atmosphere, where temperatures are colder."
> This is one example of what I'm referring to:
> 
> Granted this chart starts with a sea level temperature of 15 celsius which can influence exactly what the speed of sound is.
> 
> [http://www.fighter-planes.com/jetmach1.htm](http://www.fighter-planes.com/jetmach1.htm)

Note that that chart only shows up to 18km, and the speed of sound plateaus at the end of the range covered.

As you get into the stratosphere temperatures start to rise again.

> 
> Note that that chart only shows up to 18km, and the speed of sound plateaus at the end of the range covered.
> As you get into the stratosphere temperatures start to rise again.

Ah dang it, I play KSP too much ![:D](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cheesy.gif), I saw the 60,000 feet and my brain read it as 60,000 meters.

EDIT: That's why I love this game and community, I'm always learning stuff.

Take a look at these two forum posts:

[http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/117069-Great-New-Physics-Thread%21?p=1894742&viewfull=1#post1894742](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/117069-Great-New-Physics-Thread%21?p=1894742&viewfull=1#post1894742)

[http://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/117069-Great-New-Physics-Thread%21?p=1940443&viewfull=1#post1940443](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/117069-Great-New-Physics-Thread%21?p=1940443&viewfull=1#post1940443)

They take a close look at Temperature and Pressure on post 1.0 Kerbin.

The model follows some kind of standard atmospheric model that was scaled to fit Kerbin.

The speed of sound changes with these parameters.

> 
> The speeds of sound and light in KSP are instantaneous. I'm not sure how you got that data...

Ahahaha, good one! ![:D](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cheesy.gif)

As said NFUN, this curve curve don't relate the speed or delay for sound effects you can heard when you are exploding a tank hundreds meters aways (this is instantaneous, works in vaccum ,etc..).

But it defines the speed of the mach 1 number (thank's Chaos\_Klaus for details in links above)

 this affect the drag of your parts and so can be a really important parameter for your jets, spaceplanes, and also rockets ( is your rocket flipping strangely near 15 000m and you don't know why?).

if you go in the debug-menu/physics/drag profil and click on the multiplier button,

 you can see the curve affecting the drag depending of the mach number:

> 
> drag multiplier in KSP 1.0.4 after the patch:
> 
> \* Drag curves modified to lower transonic hump.http://imgur.com/oiui953
> 
> ![oiui953.png](http://i.imgur.com/oiui953.png)
> 
>  old drag multiplier in KSP 1.0.2:
> 
> [![prW1GTr.png](http://i.imgur.com/prW1GTr.png)](http://imgur.com/prW1GTr)
> 
> 

So, i wish my graphic will help us to better designing and piloting our ships.

Also do you know a way to record this values automatically? (the mod [graphotron](https://forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com/threads/119337-Part-1-0-Graphotron-v0-3-May-4-2015-Track-Plot-Sensor-Flight-Data) don't display the values i want)

 i would like to do it on other planets, but i'm too lazy to do it by hand again ![:P](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_tongue.gif)

**Edited <time datetime="2015-07-02T21:25:26Z" title="07/02/2015 09:25  PM" data-short="9 yr">July 2, 2015</time> by Skalou**

> 
> Ah dang it, I play KSP too much ![:D](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_k_cheesy.gif), I saw the 60,000 feet and my brain read it as 60,000 meters.
> EDIT: That's why I love this game and community, I'm always learning stuff.

Yea, I have that problem too... stupid US upbringing...

I'll be flying around thinking, oh, 12k isn't so high.... but thats really ~40,000 feet.

30 km... ~100,000 feet... which is pretty much the limit for level flight for anything we've built.

And if we assume kerbin's atmosphere is about 5/7th scale - as it seemed to be in 0.90... with a scale height of 5km, surface pressure of 1 atm, while earth has a scale height of about 7km (granted its not so simple and it to deviates from that in other atmospheric layers)... then its more like 140,000 feet...

And my knowledge of flying around at ~10k \*feet\* really only translates to flying at about 3km or less on Kerbin
In 1.0 it's an 80% atmosphere (so 12km Kerbin = 15km on Earth).

You're very welcome!

Speed of sound depends on only three things: the ratio of specific heats, the gas constant for the gas (which can be gotten by dividing the universal gas constant by the molecular weight of the gas, the latter of which KSP stores), and the temperature. Neither density nor pressure are required.

> 
> You're very welcome!
> Speed of sound depends on only three things: the ratio of specific heats, the gas constant for the gas (which can be gotten by dividing the universal gas constant by the molecular weight of the gas, the latter of which KSP stores), and the temperature

thank you, so i've looked a bit more and found the law:

![eq01.gif](http://www.aerospaceweb.org/question/atmosphere/atmosphere/eq01.gif)

 where 

- a = speed of sound [ft/s or m/s]   
 ÃŽÂ³ = specific heat ratio [dimensionless]   
 R = specific gas constant [ft-lb/slug/Ã‚Â°R or J/kg/K]   
 T = atmospheric temperature [degrees Rankine (Ã‚Â°R) or degrees Kelvin (K)]   
an intersting link to learn more on speed of sound for rocket:

[https://www.grc.nasa.gov/www/k-12/airplane/sound.html](https://www.grc.nasa.gov/www/k-12/airplane/sound.html)

Also, as Laythe as an atmosphere usable for jet engine with their thrust depenpending hardly of the mach number, it was my next target:

[Album of the trip!\[aSeheeW.png\](http://i.imgur.com/aSeheeW.png)](http://imgur.com/a/meJG3#0)

and then:

min/max speed of sound splashed: 336/340m/s

![9euI9Qv.png](http://i.imgur.com/9euI9Qv.png)

**Edited <time datetime="2015-07-08T21:39:53Z" title="07/08/2015 09:39  PM" data-short="9 yr">July 8, 2015</time> by Skalou**

> 
> As you get into the stratosphere temperatures start to rise again.

No. As you get ABOVE the stratosphere, temperatures start changing again (up and then down again). In the stratosphere temperatures are invariant with altitude. That's WHY it is the "stratosphere," because with no temperature gradient the air stratifies.

Eventually you reach a point where the air is so thin that temperature becomes more of statistical thermodynamic quantity than a fluid dynamic parameter.
